dublinCore.dc:title: 115 HR 839 IH: Public Service Spending Integrity Act
dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.

action.action-desc: Mr. Ruiz introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Oversight and Government Reform, and in addition to the Committee on House Administration, for a period to be subsequently determined by the Speaker, in each case for consideration of such provisions as fall within the jurisdiction of the committee concerned

form.official-title: To prevent the enrichment of certain Government officers and employees or their families through Federal funds or contracting, and for other purposes.

subsection.text: This Act may be cited as the Public Service Spending Integrity Act.

paragraph.text: Americans’ trust in government is essential to our democracy.
Allowing public service by an elected official to seemingly converge with their own personal gain is corrosive to Americans’ faith in government.

Members of Congress and the executive branch have substantial power and discretion over the disbursement of public funds, and with that comes the obligation to create a barrier between public service and personal gain.

section.header: Limitation on use of Federal funds and contracting at businesses owned by certain Government officers and employees

paragraph.text: Beginning in fiscal year 2017 and in each fiscal year thereafter, no Federal funds may be obligated or expended for purposes of procuring goods or services at any business owned or controlled by a covered individual or any family member of such an individual.

Beginning in fiscal year 2017 and in each fiscal year thereafter, no funds from a Members’ Representational Allowance of a Member of the House of Representatives (including a Delegate or Resident Commissioner to the Congress) or a Senators’ Official Personnel and Office Expense Account may be obligated or expended for purposes of procuring goods or services at any business owned or controlled by the Member of Congress or any family member of such a Member.

subsection.text: No federal agency may enter into a contract with a business owned or controlled by a covered individual or any family member of such an individual.

For purposes of this section, a business shall be deemed to be owned or controlled by a covered individual or any family member of such an individual, or a Member of Congress or a family member of such a Member, if the covered individual or member of family or the Member of Congress or member of family (as the case may be)—

paragraph.text: is a member of the board of directors or similar governing body of the business; or
directly or indirectly owns or controls 51 percent or more of the voting shares of the business.

subparagraph.text: the head of any Executive department (as that term is defined in section 101 of title 5, United States Code); and
any individual occupying a position designated by the President as a Cabinet-level position.

paragraph.text: The term family member means an individual with any of the following relationships to a covered individual or a Member of Congress:

subparagraph.text: Sons and daughters, and spouses thereof.
Brothers and sisters, and spouses thereof.
Grandparents and grandchildren, and spouses thereof.
Domestic partner and parents thereof, including domestic partners of any individual in paragraphs (2) through (5).

paragraph.text: The term federal agency has the meaning given that term in section 102 of title 40, United States Code.
The term Member of Congress has the meaning given that term in section 2106 of title 5, United States Code, but does not include the Vice President.
